Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2008 07:55AM 33rabk wrote: Hi Lisa! I have finally got my treatment plan, I start this coming Friday with chemo (FEC-T) 6 rounds, ne day every 3 weeks.  After chemo I will do 4-5 weeks of radiation and hormone therapy.  They are throwing everything at me to make sure they get any straggler cells that made it through the lymph nodes.  They said my sugery was successful and there was a clean margin (so that's good) but they can't be 100% sure stragglers didn't get through.  I am nervous but also anxious to get this over with.   Thanks for your concern.
Posts.Title: Waiting for Treatment Plan 33rabk sierra-noel

Posts.Content: 33rabk wrote: Good Day!  I am 33 years old and have just had a radical mastectomy on my left side and also made the decision to remove my right breast also.  I had found 2 lumps approximately 3 months ago and underwent a lumpectomy in May which showed both lumps were cancerous.  I then had a partial mastectomy with 2 lymph nodes removed the beginning of June, there was cancer cells and pre-cancer cells within the tissue and 1 of the 2 lymph nodes was positive with cancer.  I finally had the mastectomy at the end of June and we know we made the right decision because there was still cancer cells within that tissue.  My right breast was clear but I am still comfortable with the decision of removing both breasts.  Going through 3 surgeries within 6 weeks has been exhausting.  I am now waiting to go to the Cancer Clinic to discuss treatment options.  I have found the waiting the worst part, I just feel I need to move on with the treatments.  I am a fighter and I have no doubt I will beat this but I need to move forward.  I have 2 young sons, ages 4 and 7.  The 7 year old knows what is going on and I think internally is having a tough time dealing.  My 4 year old is so innocent, I love the questions that he asks, they make me laugh (which is something I need).  My husband has been wonderful and my mother has flown home to take care of me during this hard time.  I take comfort in hearing all the successful long term survival stories, because it scares me to think that my life now has a time limit on it, which I do not want to believe.  I think I just needed to vent and think that this a great opportunity to discuss with other women going through the same thing.  What a bond we have. Dx 5/28/2008, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Waiting for Treatment Plan 33rabk sierra-noel

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2008 12:05PM 33rabk wrote: Thanks Jenny!  I am so glad I signed up for this.  It's such a wonderful network and we need the support from people going through the same thing.  I can appreciate everything you said and will remember everything.  I am going to fight this and am going to stay positive that I have a long life in front of me, I just have a road block right now that I need to take care of.   The Cancer Clinic is supposed to call next week with an appointment.  My whole family is eager for that.  You are in my prayers too.   I've been watching lots of funny movies to keep me laughing.  Thanks, Angie
Posts.Title: Waiting for Treatment Plan 33rabk sierra-noel

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 04:30AM 33rabk wrote: Hi Lisa! I feel too young to have this, especially when there is no family history but I'm trying not to dwell on that.  I noticed that you had your treatments before the surgery, one of my local friends had the same.  Do you know if there is a reason for this?  I've had all my surgeries first and then I'll have treatment, most people I've spoken with had the surgeries first and then the treatment and I was just wondering if have the treatment first was new and more effective.  4-wheeling 86 miles sounds so great we love to 4-wheel and I think that sounds amazing.  I think the first thing I would like to do after all my treatment is go away on a honeymoon with my husband and children, we never had one because we both had started new jobs when we got married.  Thanks for your reply and your prayers, I appreciate all the thoughts and prayers I receive and mine go out to you also. Take care and you are right, it is only temporary.  Angie
Posts.Title: Waiting for Treatment Plan 33rabk sierra-noel

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 04:22AM 33rabk wrote: Controlmydestiny, Wow, you are going through a rough time too and you are also in my prayers.  Did you feel your lump or a routine mammogram picked it up?  My bone scans and ultra sound came back fine but I had that all done before all the cancer was removed, I think I may request to have another one done because the cancer was aggressive.  Maybe they will do it again when I get to the cancer clinic and meet my oncologists.  I just find it so overwhelming and scary.  I need to find out more information, my surgeon thinks its stage II but I guess it will be the oncologist that makes that decision.  So I really don't know what stage or grade I am at.  I'm going to look up what questions I should ask so I am prepared  when I get there. I really appreciate all the replies.  I think we all share such a strong bond.  Take care and goodluck with you liver biopsy, I will be thinking of you. Angie
Posts.Title: Waiting for Treatment Plan 33rabk sierra-noel

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 05:42AM 33rabk wrote: Hi Lisa! I completely understand how you felt, I made the decision before I even had the results of the partial that if it came back I had to have a mastectomy I would have both removed.  It was a shocking sight at first but I'm getting used to it and am so happy I made the decision I did.  I bet it does making riding the 4-wheeler more comfortable :).   Have a great day too, and love and prayer to you! Angie
Posts.Title: Waiting for Treatment Plan 33rabk sierra-noel

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 12:02PM 33rabk wrote: No news yet, I called the Cancer Clinic on Friday and they said I will hear very soon.  I'm assuming they send the appointment information through the mail instead of phone calls.  My stomach is in knots and I wake up in the morning with a very upset tummy.  I have to try to get control of my thoughts and stay positive.  Every night and every morning, I repeat that I am going to beat this for 2 minutes each time.  Thanks for your prayers, you are in mine too.  Angie
